## So Far...

We have seen that most societies start as [agrarian]{.hi}

::: {.incremental}
- Then new technology makes [agriculture more efficient]{.hi}
- Which means that fewer people need to work in agriculture
- The [surplus agricultural labor]{.hi} transitions toward the industrial sector
- But [where do they work?]{.hp} 
    - [Cities]{.h}
:::

## Migration

[What factors could be contributing to the growth of cities?]{.hi .align-center}

[We can think of two different categories:]{.h}

[_1._]{.hp .note} [Push Factors]{.hp}

::: {.incremental}
- [Lack of Economic Opportunities:]{.h} Low agricultural productivity, underemployment, unstable farm incomes
- [Poor Living Conditions]{.h} Limited access to healthcare, education, poor infrastructure
- [Environmental pressures]{.h} Drought, soil degradation, natural disasters
:::

[_2._]{.hp .note .faded .small} [Pull Factors]{.hp .faded .small}

---

## Migration

[What factors could be contributing to the growth of cities?]{.hi .align-center}

[We can think of two different categories:]{.h}

[_1._]{.hp .note .faded .small} [Push Factors]{.hp .faded .small}

[_2._]{.hp .note} [Pull Factors]{.hp}

::: {.incremental}
- [Employment prospect]{.h} Cities offer more jobs, especially in manufacturing, services, and the informal sector
- [Better Services and Amenities]{.h} Access to education, healthcare, and infrastructure draws migrants
- [Social and Lifestyle Appeal]{.h} Greater connectivity, modern lifestyles, and social mobility 
:::

---

## Key Terms

::: {.incremental .vertical-center}
- [Urban Bias:]{.hp} Governments favor urban areas over rural areas

- [Rural-to-Urban Migration:]{.hp} Movement of people from farms to urban center

- [Agglomeration Economy]{.hp} Cost advantages of grouping consumers and producers in the same area
:::
